prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: AFGL2343 - mapping the fast inner wind
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
The aim of this setup is to map the emission from the inner outflow and the high excitation shell infered from PdBI maps of HCN and 29SiO. The size expected of this shell is expected to be ~0.08''. Observing the high-excitation line CO 6-5 provides the resolution needed to spatially resolve these regions.
According to the different performance parameters listed below, the time requested for this setup is 2.60 hours, with a total of 51.64 minutes of time on-source.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The CO 6-5 line is very broad covering ~60km/s. To observe this emission line we will use the baseband 1. We have selected a correlator setup with a resolution of 0.424km/s and a bandwidth of 813km/s (1875.0 MHz).

The desired angular resolution is the highest possible at this frequencies, i.e. 0.08''. This extremelly high angular resolution is needed to resolve the high-excitation region inferred in previous interferometric maps (Quintana-Lacaci et al 2008), which has been found to be smaller than 0.24". Since the largest structure recoverable with the 12m array is largest than the expected extent of the emission, we do not need ACA observations.

The line proposed is relatively strong with an expected brightness of 0.5 Jy/beam for the bulk of the emission. Due to the large width of the molecular profile, a spectral resolution of 0.5km/s is enough to properly map the general emission as well as the emission peak. We aim for a sensitivity of 33mJy.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: IRC+10420 - 3 components - HNC 1mm
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
In this setup we aim to map the emission from HNC 3-2, 29SiO 6-5 and NO 5/2-3/2.
A high angular resolution is needed to resolve the posible outflows related with the features in the HNC emission. In addition these observations will provide an accurate determination of the region where the NO emission arises, fundamental to study the nucleosynthesis processes, and the 29SiO emission which has been related with shocked regions. We ask for a resolution of 0.17''.
Assuming that the observations are carried out in weather conditions corresponding to the 4th octile, the time requested for this setup is 1.47 hours, with a total of 39.93 minutes of time on-source.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The configuration of the correlator for this setup consists in the baseband-1 tuned to observe HNC 3-2 emission, baseband-3 tuned at the 29SiO 6-5 frequency and the baseband-4 covering the frequency of NO 5/2-3/2. Since the width of the molecular lines is particularly wide, the bandwidth selected to cover these emissions is 468.750MHz (~500km/s), while the resolution is ~0.3km/s, which allows a good coverage and spectral resolution of the proposed lines.

The desired angular resolution is the highest possible at this frequencies, i.e. 0.17''. This high angular resolution is needed to obtain the most accurate information on the outflows present in IRC+10420. Since the largest structure recoverable with the 12m array is largest than the expected extent of the emission, we do not need ACA observations.

In this setup we propose to observe HNC 3-2. This emission line presents three spectral features with similar intensities. In addition to this line, we will observe NO 5/2-3/2 and 29SiO 6-5. The estimated peak flux density is 158mJy/beam. Due to the large width of the molecular profile, a spectral resolution of 0.5km/s is enough to properly map the different spectral features. We aim for a sensitivity of 3mJy. This high sensitivity is needed to obtain the highest SNR for NO and 29SiO maps.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: AFGL2343 - Molecular structure high resolution maps
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
In this setup we propose to map the global structure of the molecular gas with a very good spatial resolution of AFGL2343. For this purpose, we propose to map the line emission of 12CO 3-2 and 13CO 3-2 with a spatial resolution of 0.2''.
In addition to this, we would map the 29SiO 8-7 emission, which has been propose to be related with shocks.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We used the baseband-1 to map 12CO 3-2 emission, baseband-2 for 29SiO 8-7 and baseband-3 for 13CO 3-2. Since the emission lines are particularly vroad a large bandwidth is needed. We selected for all basebands a bandwidth of 468.750MHz (~400km/s).
The spectral resolution ranged from 0.2 to 0.3km/s. This resolution could be smoothed to obtain a higher SNR.

We aim for a spatial resolution of 0.2'' to be able to resolve the major structures in the CSE around this objects. The largest extended structure we expect to detect, as observed in 1'' resolution maps, has a size of 5''. Therefore, no ACA observations are needed.

The lines included in this setup are 12CO 3-2, 13CO 3-2 and 29SiO 6-5. The peak brightness expected for 12CO 3-2 is 55mJy/beam. Due to the large width of the line profiles a resolution of 1km/s is enough to obtain high quality maps. The sensitivity we expect to obtain is 3.9mJy.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: IRC+10420 - Molecular structure high resolution maps
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
In this setup we propose to map the global structure of the molecular gas with a very good spatial resolution of IRC+10420. For this purpose, we propose to map the line emission of 12CO 3-2 and 13CO 3-2 with a spatial resolution of 0.2''.
In addition to this, we would map the 29SiO 8-7 emission, which has been propose to be related with shocks.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We used the baseband-1 to map 12CO 3-2 emission, baseband-2 for 29SiO 8-7 and baseband-3 for 13CO 3-2. Since the emission lines are particularly broad a large bandwidth is needed. We selected for all basebands a bandwidth of 468.750MHz (~400km/s). The spectral resolution ranged from 0.2 to 0.3km/s.

We aim for a spatial resolution of 0.2'' to be able to resolve the major structures in the CSE around this objects. The largest extended structure we expect to detect, as observed in 1'' resolution maps, has a size of 5''. Therefore, no ACA observations are needed.

The lines included in this setup are 12CO 3-2, 13CO 3-2 and 29SiO 6-5. The peak flux density expected for 12CO 3-2 is 125mJy/beam. Due to the large width of the line profiles a resolution of 1km/s is enough to obtain high quality maps. The sensitivity we expect to obtain is 3.9mJy.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract:
The yellow hypergiant stars (YHGs) are some of the most extreme objects in the Universe. The two YHGs AFGL2343 and IRC+10420 have been extensively studied in molecular emission with a typical resolution of 1". While the bulk of their emission was found to be distributed spherically, denoting an isotropical mass loss ejections, certain features support a more complex scenario.
IRC+10420 seems to present a cold outflow. On the contrary, AFGL2343 presents hot accelerated gas in its innermost regions.
Understanding the shaping of the circumstellar envelopes (CSEs) around these objects is essential to obtain a global undestaning of the late evolution of massive stars. However, the resolution of the maps obtained so far avoided detailed studies of these regions.
We propose to obtain CO 3-2 maps with an angular resolution of 0.2" to study the properties of the global molecular gas. In addition, we propose to obtain interferometric maps with high angular resolution of HNC 3-2 for IRC+10420 (0.17") and CO 6-5 for AFGL2343 (0.08"). The former spectral setup would also allow us to obtain maps of NO, a key molecule to study enrichment in Nitrogen observed for IRC+10420.

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: Group of Molecular Astrophysics, ICMM CSIC
